intro: Juanulloa hookeriana, commonly known as the Hooker's juanulloa, is a flowering plant native to the Andean regions of South America. It belongs to the family Malvaceae, which includes hibiscus and cotton. The plant is characterized by its woody stems and showy, pentagonal flowers that are typically pink or red in color. It thrives in high-altitude environments and is often found in cloud forests. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a rare and ecologically significant species.
